title: An Overview of gssr
text: General Social Survey, GSS, one cornerstones American social science one -analyzed datasets Sociology. routinely used research, teaching, reference point discussions changes American society since early 1970s. also model open, public data. National Opinion Research Center already provides many excellent tools working data, long made freely available researchers. Casual users GSS can examine GSS Data Explorer, social scientists can download complete datasets directly. present, GSS provided researchers variety commercial formats: Stata (.dta), SAS, SPSS (.sav). ’s difficult get data R using Haven package, can little annoying repeatedly, across projects. one many times, got tired made package instead. Currently, gssr package provides Release 1 GSS Cumulative Data File (1972-2024); three GSS Three Wave Panel Data Files (panels beginning 2006, 2008, 2010, respectively); 2020 panel file. package also integrates codebook information variables R’s help system, allowing accessed via help browser console ?. gssr package makes GSS little accessible users R, free software environment statistical computing, thus helps small way make GSS even open already .

title: An Overview of gssr
text: article makes use additional packages beyond gssr . assumption users gssr likely use analyze data conjunction combination Tidyverse tools survey, srvyr, panelr packages.
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2) library(haven) library(tibble) library(survey) #> Loading required package: grid #> Loading required package: Matrix #> Loading required package: survival #>  #> Attaching package: 'survey' #> The following object is masked from 'package:graphics': #>  #>     dotchart library(srvyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'srvyr' #> The following object is masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter

what: Load the gssr package and its data
title: An Overview of gssr
text: begin Cumulative Data file (1972-2024). startup message notes, data objects automatically loaded. , use R’s “lazy loading” functionality. main GSS dataset rather large. Instead load manually data(). purposes vignette, full Cumulative Data object big, use just columns stored object called gss_sub. code also work full dataset object, gss_all, can load command data(gss_all). GSS data comes labelled format, mirroring way encoded Stata SPSS platforms. numeric codes content column cells. labeling information stored attribute column. use label information later recoding variables , say, character factor variables.
code: library(gssr) #> Package loaded. To attach the GSS data, type data(gss_all) at the console. #> For the panel data and documentation, type e.g. data(gss_panel08_long) and data(gss_panel_doc). #> For help on a specific GSS variable, type ?varname at the console. data(gss_sub) gss_sub #> # A tibble: 75,699 × 20 #>    year         id ballot      age   race    sex     degree  padeg   madeg       #>    <dbl+lbl> <dbl> <dbl+lbl>   <dbl> <dbl+l> <dbl+l> <dbl+l> <dbl+l> <dbl+lbl>   #>  1 1972          1 NA(i) [iap] 23    1 [whi… 2 [fem… 3 [bac… 0 [les… NA(i) [iap] #>  2 1972          2 NA(i) [iap] 70    1 [whi… 1 [mal… 0 [les… 0 [les…     0 [les… #>  3 1972          3 NA(i) [iap] 48    1 [whi… 2 [fem… 1 [hig… 0 [les…     0 [les… #>  4 1972          4 NA(i) [iap] 27    1 [whi… 2 [fem… 3 [bac… 3 [bac…     1 [hig… #>  5 1972          5 NA(i) [iap] 61    1 [whi… 2 [fem… 1 [hig… 0 [les…     0 [les… #>  6 1972          6 NA(i) [iap] 26    1 [whi… 1 [mal… 1 [hig… 3 [bac…     4 [gra… #>  7 1972          7 NA(i) [iap] 28    1 [whi… 1 [mal… 1 [hig… 3 [bac…     1 [hig… #>  8 1972          8 NA(i) [iap] 27    1 [whi… 1 [mal… 3 [bac… 3 [bac…     1 [hig… #>  9 1972          9 NA(i) [iap] 21    2 [bla… 2 [fem… 1 [hig… 1 [hig…     1 [hig… #> 10 1972         10 NA(i) [iap] 30    2 [bla… 2 [fem… 1 [hig… 0 [les…     0 [les… #> # ℹ 75,689 more rows #> # ℹ 11 more variables: relig <dbl+lbl>, polviews <dbl+lbl>, fefam <dbl+lbl>, #> #   vpsu <dbl+lbl>, vstrat <dbl+lbl>, oversamp <dbl+lbl>, formwt <dbl+lbl>, #> #   wtssall <dbl+lbl>, wtssps <dbl+lbl>, sampcode <dbl+lbl>, sample <dbl+lbl>

what: Descriptive analysis of the data: an example
title: An Overview of gssr
text: GSS complex survey. working , need take structure account order properly calculate statistics population mean variable year, standard error, . tasks use survey srvyr packages. details survey, see Lumley (2010). also recoding prior analyzing data, load several additional tidyverse packages assist us. examine topic subject recent media attention, New York Times elsewhere, regarding beliefs young men gender roles. surveys seemed point recent increasing conservatism front amongst young men. happens, GSS longstanding question named fefam, respondents asked give opinion following statement: much better everyone involved man achiever outside home woman takes care home family. Respondents may answer Strongly Agree, Agree, Disagree, Strongly Disagree statement (well refusing answer, saying don’t know).

text: Variable summaries cumulative data file built gssr integrated R’s help system. example, can type ?fefam console variable’s documentation appear documentation browser.  Scrolling give summary values variable can take.

previous_headings: Descriptive analysis of the data: an example
title: An Overview of gssr
text: GSS data retains labeling information (originally imported via haven package). working data analysis, probably want convert labeled variables data types factors. done care (whole dataset ). Typically, want focus relatively small subset variables examine . example, let’s say want explore fefam question. subset data prepare analysis. going subset gss_sub object called gss_fam containing just variables want examine, along core measures identify respondents (id year) variables necessary survey weighting later (wtssps).
code: cont_vars <- c("year", "id", "ballot", "age")  cat_vars <- c("race", "sex", "fefam")  wt_vars <- c("vpsu",              "vstrat",              "oversamp",              "formwt",              # weight to deal with experimental randomization              "wtssps",              # weight variable              "sampcode",            # sampling error code              "sample")              # sampling frame and method  my_vars <- c(cont_vars, cat_vars, wt_vars)  gss_fam <- gss_sub |>   select(all_of(my_vars))  gss_fam #> # A tibble: 75,699 × 14 #>    year         id ballot      age       race    sex     fefam       vpsu        #>    <dbl+lbl> <dbl> <dbl+lbl>   <dbl+lbl> <dbl+l> <dbl+l> <dbl+lbl>   <dbl+lbl>   #>  1 1972          1 NA(i) [iap] 23        1 [whi… 2 [fem… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] #>  2 1972          2 NA(i) [iap] 70        1 [whi… 1 [mal… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] #>  3 1972          3 NA(i) [iap] 48        1 [whi… 2 [fem… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] #>  4 1972          4 NA(i) [iap] 27        1 [whi… 2 [fem… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] #>  5 1972          5 NA(i) [iap] 61        1 [whi… 2 [fem… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] #>  6 1972          6 NA(i) [iap] 26        1 [whi… 1 [mal… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] #>  7 1972          7 NA(i) [iap] 28        1 [whi… 1 [mal… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] #>  8 1972          8 NA(i) [iap] 27        1 [whi… 1 [mal… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] #>  9 1972          9 NA(i) [iap] 21        2 [bla… 2 [fem… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] #> 10 1972         10 NA(i) [iap] 30        2 [bla… 2 [fem… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] #> # ℹ 75,689 more rows #> # ℹ 6 more variables: vstrat <dbl+lbl>, oversamp <dbl+lbl>, formwt <dbl+lbl>, #> #   wtssps <dbl+lbl>, sampcode <dbl+lbl>, sample <dbl+lbl>

previous_headings: Descriptive analysis of the data: an example
title: An Overview of gssr
text: Next, recoding create new variables. also create new variables: age quintiles, variable flagging whether respondent 25 younger, recoded fefam binary “Agree” “Disagree” (non-responses dropped). begin figuring cutpoints age quintiles. Next, clean gss_fam bit, discarding label missing value information don’t need. data gss_all retains labeling structure provided GSS. Variables stored numerically labels attached . Often, using data R, convenient convert categorical variables interested character factor type instead.
code: qrts <- quantile(as.numeric(gss_fam$age),                   na.rm = TRUE) qrts #>   0%  25%  50%  75% 100%  #>   18   32   44   60   89  quintiles <- quantile(as.numeric(gss_fam$age),                        probs = seq(0, 1, 0.2), na.rm = TRUE)  quintiles #>   0%  20%  40%  60%  80% 100%  #>   18   30   39   50   64   89 ## Recoding ## The convert_agegrp() and capwords() functions seen here are defined ## at the top of the Rmd file used to produce this document.  gss_fam <- gss_fam |>   mutate(     # Convert all missing to NA     across(everything(), haven::zap_missing),      # Convert all weight vars to numeric     across(all_of(wt_vars), as.numeric),     # Make all categorical variables factors and relabel nicely     across(all_of(cat_vars), forcats::as_factor),     across(all_of(cat_vars), \(x) forcats::fct_relabel(x, capwords, strict = TRUE)),     # Create the age groups     ageq = cut(x = age, breaks = unique(qrts), include.lowest = TRUE),     ageq =  forcats::fct_relabel(ageq, convert_agegrp),      agequint = cut(x = age, breaks = unique(quintiles), include.lowest = TRUE),     agequint = forcats::fct_relabel(agequint, convert_agegrp),     year_f = droplevels(factor(year)),     young = ifelse(age < 26, "Yes", "No"),     # Dichotomize fefam     fefam = forcats::fct_recode(fefam, NULL = "IAP", NULL = "DK", NULL = "NA"),     fefam_d = forcats::fct_recode(fefam,                                   Agree = "Strongly Agree",                                   Disagree = "Strongly Disagree"),     fefam_n = recode(fefam_d, "Agree" = 0, "Disagree" = 1),     samplerc = case_when(sample %in% c(3:4) ~ 3,                                sample %in% c(6:7) ~ 6,                               .default = sample))  ## Some of the recoded variables gss_fam |>   filter(year > 1976) |>    select(race:fefam, agequint:fefam_d) |>    relocate(year_f) #> # A tibble: 68,109 × 7 #>    year_f race  sex    fefam             agequint  young fefam_d  #>    <fct>  <fct> <fct>  <fct>             <fct>     <chr> <fct>    #>  1 1977   White Female Agree             Age 50-64 No    Agree    #>  2 1977   White Female Agree             Age 30-39 No    Agree    #>  3 1977   White Male   Strongly Agree    Age 64+   No    Agree    #>  4 1977   White Male   Strongly Disagree Age 18-30 No    Disagree #>  5 1977   White Female Agree             Age 18-30 Yes   Agree    #>  6 1977   White Male   Disagree          Age 30-39 No    Disagree #>  7 1977   White Female Agree             Age 64+   No    Agree    #>  8 1977   White Female Disagree          Age 30-39 No    Disagree #>  9 1977   White Female Agree             Age 64+   No    Agree    #> 10 1977   White Female Disagree          Age 39-50 No    Disagree #> # ℹ 68,099 more rows

previous_headings: Descriptive analysis of the data: an example
title: An Overview of gssr
text: point can calculate percentages, percent male female respondents disagreeing fefam proposition year. However, calculations take GSS survey design account. set data can properly calculate population means errors . use svyr package’s wrappers survey . gss_svy object contains data gss_fam, incorporates information sampling structure way survey package’s functions can work :
code: gss_fam |>    group_by(year, sex, young, fefam_d) |>    tally() |>    drop_na() |>    mutate(pct = round((n/sum(n))*100, 1)) |>    select(-n)  #> # A tibble: 192 × 5 #> # Groups:   year, sex, young [96] #>    year      sex    young fefam_d    pct #>    <dbl+lbl> <fct>  <chr> <fct>    <dbl> #>  1 1977      Male   No    Agree     71.8 #>  2 1977      Male   No    Disagree  28.2 #>  3 1977      Male   Yes   Agree     54.3 #>  4 1977      Male   Yes   Disagree  45.7 #>  5 1977      Female No    Agree     66.6 #>  6 1977      Female No    Disagree  33.4 #>  7 1977      Female Yes   Agree     41.9 #>  8 1977      Female Yes   Disagree  58.1 #>  9 1985      Male   No    Agree     53.6 #> 10 1985      Male   No    Disagree  46.4 #> # ℹ 182 more rows options(survey.lonely.psu = "adjust") options(na.action="na.pass")  gss_svy <- gss_fam |>     filter(year > 1974) |>     tidyr::drop_na(fefam_d, young) |>     mutate(stratvar = interaction(year, vstrat)) |>     as_survey_design(id = vpsu,                      strata = stratvar,                      weights = wtssps,                      nest = TRUE) gss_svy #> Stratified 1 - level Cluster Sampling design (with replacement) #> With (6111) clusters. #> Called via srvyr #> Sampling variables: #>   - ids: vpsu  #>   - strata: stratvar  #>   - weights: wtssps  #> Data variables:  #>   - year (dbl+lbl), id (dbl), ballot (dbl+lbl), age (dbl+lbl), race (fct), sex #>     (fct), fefam (fct), vpsu (dbl), vstrat (dbl), oversamp (dbl), formwt (dbl), #>     wtssps (dbl), sampcode (dbl), sample (dbl), ageq (fct), agequint (fct), #>     year_f (fct), young (chr), fefam_d (fct), fefam_n (dbl), samplerc (dbl), #>     stratvar (fct)

previous_headings: Descriptive analysis of the data: an example
title: An Overview of gssr
text: ’re now position calculate properly-weighted summary statistics variable ’re interested , every year data.
code: ## Get the breakdown for every year out_ff <- gss_svy |>     group_by(year, sex, young, fefam_d) |>     summarize(prop = survey_mean(na.rm = TRUE, vartype = "ci")) |>    drop_na(sex) #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `dplyr::summarise()`. #> ℹ In argument: `prop = survey_mean(na.rm = TRUE, vartype = "ci")`. #> ℹ In group 1: `year = 1977`, `sex = Male`, `young = "No"`, `fefam_d = Agree`. #> Caused by warning: #> ! na.rm argument has no effect on survey_mean when calculating grouped proportions.  #> This warning is displayed once per session.  out_ff #> # A tibble: 192 × 7 #> # Groups:   year, sex, young [96] #>    year      sex    young fefam_d   prop prop_low prop_upp #>    <dbl+lbl> <fct>  <chr> <fct>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1 1977      Male   No    Agree    0.708    0.662    0.754 #>  2 1977      Male   No    Disagree 0.292    0.246    0.338 #>  3 1977      Male   Yes   Agree    0.544    0.461    0.627 #>  4 1977      Male   Yes   Disagree 0.456    0.373    0.539 #>  5 1977      Female No    Agree    0.673    0.636    0.711 #>  6 1977      Female No    Disagree 0.327    0.289    0.364 #>  7 1977      Female Yes   Agree    0.417    0.312    0.522 #>  8 1977      Female Yes   Disagree 0.583    0.478    0.688 #>  9 1985      Male   No    Agree    0.541    0.489    0.594 #> 10 1985      Male   No    Disagree 0.459    0.406    0.511 #> # ℹ 182 more rows

previous_headings: Descriptive analysis of the data: an example
title: An Overview of gssr
text: finish polished plot trends fefam time, men women two (recoded) age groups time.
code:
theme_set(theme_minimal())  facet_names <- c("No" = "Age Over 25 when surveyed",                   "Yes" = "Age 18-25 when surveyed") fefam_txt <- "Disagreement with the statement, ‘It is much better for
everyone involved if the man is the achiever outside the
home and the woman takes care of the home and family’"  out_ff |>    filter(fefam_d == "Disagree") |>   ggplot(mapping =             aes(x = year, y = prop,                ymin = prop_low,                 ymax = prop_upp,                color = sex,                 group = sex,                 fill = sex)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_ribbon(alpha = 0.3, color = NA) +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1978, 2022, 4)) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1)) +   scale_color_manual(values = my_colors("bly")[2:1],                      labels = c("Men", "Women"),                      guide = guide_legend(title=NULL)) +   scale_fill_manual(values = my_colors("bly")[2:1],                     labels = c("Men", "Women"),                     guide = guide_legend(title=NULL)) +   facet_wrap(~ young, labeller = as_labeller(facet_names),              ncol = 1) +   coord_cartesian(xlim = c(1977, 2022)) +   labs(x = "Year",        y = "Percent Disagreeing",        subtitle = fefam_txt,        caption = "Kieran Healy http://socviz.co.
          Data source: General Social Survey") +   theme(legend.position = "bottom")

title: An Overview of gssr
text: addition Cumulative Data File, gssr package also includes GSS’s panel data. current rotating panel design began 2006. panel respondents interviewed year followed interviews 2008 2010. second panel interviewed beginning 2008, followed interviews 2010 2012. third panel began 2010, follow-interviews 2012 2014. gssr package provides three datasets, one three-wave panels. gss_panel06_long, gss_panel08_long, gss_panel10_long. datasets provided GSS wide format (names suggest) packaged long format. conversion carried using panelr package long_panel() function. Conversion long back wide format possible tools provided panelr. load panel data . example: panel data objects created panelr regular tibbles. column names long format wave identifiers. Rather, firstid wave variables track cases. firstid variable unique every row missing values. id variable GSS tracks individuals within waves. can look attrition across waves , e.g.:
code: data(gss_panel06_long)  gss_panel06_long #> # A tibble: 6,000 × 1,572 #>    firstid ballot   form   formwt oversamp sampcode sample samptype vstrat  vpsu #>    <fct>   <fct>    <fct>   <dbl>    <dbl> <fct>    <fct>  <fct>     <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 0009    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  2 0009    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  3 0009    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  4 0010    Ballot a Stand…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  5 0010    Ballot a Stand…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  6 0010    Ballot a Stand…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  7 0011    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  8 0011    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  9 0011    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #> 10 0012    Ballot a Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1958     1 #> # ℹ 5,990 more rows #> # ℹ 1,562 more variables: wtpan12 <dbl>, wtpan123 <dbl>, wtpannr12 <dbl>, #> #   wtpannr123 <dbl>, letin1a <fct>, wave <dbl>, abany <fct>, abdefect <fct>, #> #   abhlth <fct>, abnomore <fct>, abpoor <fct>, abrape <fct>, absingle <fct>, #> #   accntsci <fct>, acqasian <fct>, acqattnd <fct>, acqblack <fct>, #> #   acqbrnda <fct>, acqchild <fct>, acqcohab <fct>, acqcon <fct>, #> #   acqcops <fct>, acqdems <fct>, acqelecs <fct>, acqfmasn <fct>, … gss_panel06_long |> select(firstid, wave, id, sex) #> # A tibble: 6,000 × 4 #>    firstid  wave id    sex    #>    <fct>   <dbl> <fct> <fct>  #>  1 0009        1 9     Female #>  2 0009        2 3001  Female #>  3 0009        3 6001  Female #>  4 0010        1 10    Female #>  5 0010        2 3002  Female #>  6 0010        3 6002  Female #>  7 0011        1 11    Female #>  8 0011        2 3003  Female #>  9 0011        3 6003  Female #> 10 0012        1 12    Male   #> # ℹ 5,990 more rows gss_panel06_long |>    select(wave, id) |>   group_by(wave) |>   summarize(observed = n_distinct(id),             missing = sum(is.na(id))) #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>    wave observed missing #>   <dbl>    <int>   <int> #> 1     1     2000       0 #> 2     2     1537     464 #> 3     3     1277     724

title: An Overview of gssr
text: Lumley, Thomas (2010). Complex Surveys: Guide Analysis Using R. New York: Wiley.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kieran Healy. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Healy K (2024). gssr: General Social Survey data use R. R package version 0.8.0, http://kjhealy.github.io/gssr.
code: @Manual{gssr,   title = {gssr: General Social Survey data for use in R},   author = {Kieran Healy},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.8.0},   url = {http://kjhealy.github.io/gssr}, }

what: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R
title: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R
text: General Social Survey Cumulative Data (1972-2024, release 1) Panel Data files packaged easy use R. companion package gssr gssrdoc, integrates GSS codebook R’s help system. recommend install packages.

title: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R
text: gssr data package, bundling several datasets convenient format. relatively large size data package means suitable hosting CRAN, core R package repository. true {gssrdoc}.

title: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R
text: R Universe provides binary packages gssr {gssrdoc}. install packages, copy paste following code R console: packages dependencies CRAN, add CRAN well R Universe repos argument. binary packages install noticeably quicker building package source. Plus, can use install.packages() directly.
code: # Install 'gssr' from 'ropensci' universe install.packages('gssr', repos =   c('https://kjhealy.r-universe.dev', 'https://cloud.r-project.org'))  # Also recommended: install 'gssrdoc' as well install.packages('gssrdoc', repos =   c('https://kjhealy.r-universe.dev', 'https://cloud.r-project.org'))

title: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R
text: can also install gssr GitHub :
code: remotes::install_github("kjhealy/gssr")

title: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R
code: library(gssr) #> Package loaded. To attach the GSS data, type data(gss_all) at the console. #> For the codebook, type data(gss_dict). #> For the panel data and documentation, type e.g. data(gss_panel08_long) and data(gss_panel_doc). #> For help on a specific GSS variable, type ?varname at the console.

title: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R
text: can get data single GSS year using gss_get_yr() download NORC put directly tibble.
code: gss18 <- gss_get_yr(2018) #> Fetching: https://gss.norc.org/documents/stata/2018_stata.zip  gss18 #> # A tibble: 2,348 × 1,083 #>    year         id wrkstat   hrs1        hrs2        evwork      wrkslf  wrkgovt #>    <dbl+lbl> <dbl> <dbl+lbl> <dbl+lbl>   <dbl+lbl>   <dbl+lbl>   <dbl+l> <dbl+l> #>  1 2018          1 3 [with … NA(i) [iap]    41       NA(i) [iap] 2 [som… 2 [pri… #>  2 2018          2 5 [retir… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap]     1 [yes] 2 [som… 2 [pri… #>  3 2018          3 1 [worki…    40       NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 2 [som… 2 [pri… #>  4 2018          4 1 [worki…    40       NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 2 [som… 2 [pri… #>  5 2018          5 5 [retir… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap]     1 [yes] 2 [som… 2 [pri… #>  6 2018          6 5 [retir… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap]     1 [yes] 2 [som… 2 [pri… #>  7 2018          7 1 [worki…    35       NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 2 [som… 1 [gov… #>  8 2018          8 1 [worki…    89 [89+… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 2 [som… 2 [pri… #>  9 2018          9 1 [worki…    40       NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 1 [sel… 2 [pri… #> 10 2018         10 1 [worki…    40       NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 2 [som… 2 [pri… #> # ℹ 2,338 more rows #> # ℹ 1,075 more variables: occ10 <dbl+lbl>, prestg10 <dbl+lbl>, #> #   prestg105plus <dbl+lbl>, indus10 <dbl+lbl>, marital <dbl+lbl>, #> #   martype <dbl+lbl>, divorce <dbl+lbl>, widowed <dbl+lbl>, #> #   spwrksta <dbl+lbl>, sphrs1 <dbl+lbl>, sphrs2 <dbl+lbl>, spevwork <dbl+lbl>, #> #   cowrksta <dbl+lbl>, cowrkslf <dbl+lbl>, coevwork <dbl+lbl>, #> #   cohrs1 <dbl+lbl>, cohrs2 <dbl+lbl>, spwrkslf <dbl+lbl>, …

title: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R

(, gssr use R’s “lazy loading” facility. data file big without error.) load () datasets, first load library use data() make data available. example, load cumulative GSS file like : take moment. ready, gss_all object available use usual way:
code: data(gss_all) gss_all #> # A tibble: 72,390 × 6,694 #>    year         id wrkstat    hrs1        hrs2        evwork      occ   prestige #>    <dbl+lbl> <dbl> <dbl+lbl>  <dbl+lbl>   <dbl+lbl>   <dbl+lbl>   <dbl> <dbl+lb> #>  1 1972          1 1 [workin… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 205   50       #>  2 1972          2 5 [retire… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap]     1 [yes] 441   45       #>  3 1972          3 2 [workin… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 270   44       #>  4 1972          4 1 [workin… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap]   1   57       #>  5 1972          5 7 [keepin… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap]     1 [yes] 385   40       #>  6 1972          6 1 [workin… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 281   49       #>  7 1972          7 1 [workin… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 522   41       #>  8 1972          8 1 [workin… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 314   36       #>  9 1972          9 2 [workin… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 912   26       #> 10 1972         10 1 [workin… NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] NA(i) [iap] 984   18       #> # ℹ 72,380 more rows #> # ℹ 6,686 more variables: wrkslf <dbl+lbl>, wrkgovt <dbl+lbl>, #> #   commute <dbl+lbl>, industry <dbl+lbl>, occ80 <dbl+lbl>, prestg80 <dbl+lbl>, #> #   indus80 <dbl+lbl>, indus07 <dbl+lbl>, occonet <dbl+lbl>, found <dbl+lbl>, #> #   occ10 <dbl+lbl>, occindv <dbl+lbl>, occstatus <dbl+lbl>, occtag <dbl+lbl>, #> #   prestg10 <dbl+lbl>, prestg105plus <dbl+lbl>, indus10 <dbl+lbl>, #> #   indstatus <dbl+lbl>, indtag <dbl+lbl>, marital <dbl+lbl>, …

what: Which questions were asked in which years?
title: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R
text: often want know years question group questions asked. can find one variables gss_which_years(). querying one variable, use c():
code: gss_which_years(gss_all, fefam)  #> # A tibble: 35 x 2 #>     year fefam #>    <dbl> <lgl> #>  1  1972 FALSE #>  2  1973 FALSE #>  3  1974 FALSE #>  4  1975 FALSE #>  5  1976 FALSE #>  6  1977 TRUE  #>  7  1978 FALSE #>  8  1980 FALSE #>  9  1982 FALSE #> 10  1983 FALSE #> # … with 25 more rows gss_all |>    gss_which_years(c(industry, indus80, wrkgovt, commute)) |>    print(n = Inf)  # A tibble: 35 × 5    year      industry indus80 wrkgovt commute    <dbl+lbl> <lgl>    <lgl>   <lgl>   <lgl>   ## 1972      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1973      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1974      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1975      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1976      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1977      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1978      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1980      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1982      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1983      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1984      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1985      TRUE     FALSE   TRUE    FALSE   ## 1986      TRUE     FALSE   TRUE    TRUE    ## 1987      TRUE     FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 1988      TRUE     TRUE    FALSE   FALSE   ## 1989      TRUE     TRUE    FALSE   FALSE   ## 1990      TRUE     TRUE    FALSE   FALSE   ## 1991      FALSE    TRUE    FALSE   FALSE   ## 1993      FALSE    TRUE    FALSE   FALSE   ## 1994      FALSE    TRUE    FALSE   FALSE   ## 1996      FALSE    TRUE    FALSE   FALSE   ## 1998      FALSE    TRUE    FALSE   FALSE   ## 2000      FALSE    TRUE    TRUE    FALSE   ## 2002      FALSE    TRUE    TRUE    FALSE   ## 2004      FALSE    TRUE    TRUE    FALSE   ## 2006      FALSE    TRUE    TRUE    FALSE   ## 2008      FALSE    TRUE    TRUE    FALSE   ## 2010      FALSE    TRUE    TRUE    FALSE   ## 2012      FALSE    FALSE   TRUE    FALSE   ## 2014      FALSE    FALSE   TRUE    FALSE   ## 2016      FALSE    FALSE   TRUE    FALSE   ## 2018      FALSE    FALSE   TRUE    FALSE   ## 2021      FALSE    FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 2022      FALSE    FALSE   FALSE   FALSE   ## 2024      FALSE    FALSE   FALSE   FALSE

title: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R
text: addition Cumulative Data File, gssr package also includes GSS’s panel data. current rotating panel design began 2006. panel respondents interviewed year followed interviews 2008 2010. second panel interviewed beginning 2008, followed interviews 2010 2012. third panel began 2010, follow-interviews 2012 2014. gssr package provides three datasets, one three-wave panels. gss_panel06_long, gss_panel08_long, gss_panel10_long. datasets provided GSS wide format (names suggest) packaged long format. 2020 panel exception , reasons described . conversion carried using panelr package long_panel() function. Conversion long back wide format possible tools provided panelr. panel data objects must loaded way cumulative data file, using data(). Panel data objects regular tibbles. need use panelr work data. column names long format wave identifiers. Rather, firstid wave variables track cases. firstid variable unique every respondent panel missing values. wave variable indexes responses given firstid panelist wave (observed). id variable GSS indexes individuals within waves. can look attrition across waves , e.g.:
code: data("gss_panel06_long")  gss_panel06_long #> # A tibble: 6,000 × 1,572 #>    firstid ballot   form   formwt oversamp sampcode sample samptype vstrat  vpsu #>    <fct>   <fct>    <fct>   <dbl>    <dbl> <fct>    <fct>  <fct>     <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 0009    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  2 0009    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  3 0009    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  4 0010    Ballot a Stand…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  5 0010    Ballot a Stand…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  6 0010    Ballot a Stand…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  7 0011    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  8 0011    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #>  9 0011    Ballot c Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1957     2 #> 10 0012    Ballot a Alter…      1        1 501      2000 … 2006 Sa…   1958     1 #> # ℹ 5,990 more rows #> # ℹ 1,562 more variables: wtpan12 <dbl>, wtpan123 <dbl>, wtpannr12 <dbl>, #> #   wtpannr123 <dbl>, letin1a <fct>, wave <dbl>, abany <fct>, abdefect <fct>, #> #   abhlth <fct>, abnomore <fct>, abpoor <fct>, abrape <fct>, absingle <fct>, #> #   accntsci <fct>, acqasian <fct>, acqattnd <fct>, acqblack <fct>, #> #   acqbrnda <fct>, acqchild <fct>, acqcohab <fct>, acqcon <fct>, #> #   acqcops <fct>, acqdems <fct>, acqelecs <fct>, acqfmasn <fct>, … data("gss_panel08_long")  gss_panel08_long  |>     select(firstid, wave, id, sex) #> # A tibble: 6,069 × 4 #>    firstid  wave id    sex   #>    <fct>   <dbl> <fct> <fct> #>  1 0001        1 1     Male  #>  2 0001        2 8001  Male  #>  3 0001        3 <NA>  <NA>  #>  4 0002        1 2     Male  #>  5 0002        2 8002  Male  #>  6 0002        3 8001  Male  #>  7 0003        1 3     Male  #>  8 0003        2 8003  Male  #>  9 0003        3 8002  Male  #> 10 0004        1 4     Male  #> # ℹ 6,059 more rows gss_panel06_long |>    select(wave, id) |>   group_by(wave) |>   summarize(observed = n_distinct(id),             missing = sum(is.na(id))) #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>    wave observed missing #>   <dbl>    <int>   <int> #> 1     1     2000       0 #> 2     2     1537     464 #> 3     3     1277     724

title: US General Social Survey (GSS) Data for R
text: COVID-19 pandemic also affected panel data design. 2020, GSS run two studies; namely, (1) panel re-interview past respondents 2016 2018 cross sectional GSS studies (referred 2016-2020 GSS Panel), (2) independent fresh cross-sectional address-based sampling push web study (referred 2020 cross-sectional survey). gssr package provides data first study gss_panel20. study empaneled former 2016 2018 GSS respondents answer GSS questionnaire 2020 (.e., 2016-2020 GSS panel). 2016-2020 GSS Panel, variables contain data one three years. differentiate versions variable, appended suffixes. Variables 2016 (Wave 1a) _1a appended, variables 2018 (Wave 1b) _1b appended, variables 2020 (Wave 2) _2 appended. Users can also track cases 2016 2018, reinterviews 2020 variable samptype. Unlike panels, data provided wide format. Users strongly encouraged read official documentation NORC website.
code: data("gss_panel20") gss_panel20 #> # A tibble: 5,215 × 4,296 #>    samptype           yearid fileversion panstat wtssall_1a wtssall_1b wtssall_2 #>    <dbl+lbl>          <chr>  <chr>       <dbl+l>      <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl> #>  1 2016 [sample from… 20160… GSS 2020 P… 1 [sel…      0.957         NA     1.09  #>  2 2016 [sample from… 20160… GSS 2020 P… 1 [sel…      0.478         NA     0.543 #>  3 2016 [sample from… 20160… GSS 2020 P… 0 [not…      0.957         NA    NA     #>  4 2016 [sample from… 20160… GSS 2020 P… 1 [sel…      1.91          NA     2.17  #>  5 2016 [sample from… 20160… GSS 2020 P… 0 [not…      1.44          NA    NA     #>  6 2016 [sample from… 20160… GSS 2020 P… 2 [sel…      0.957         NA    NA     #>  7 2016 [sample from… 20160… GSS 2020 P… 0 [not…      1.44          NA    NA     #>  8 2016 [sample from… 20160… GSS 2020 P… 1 [sel…      0.957         NA     1.09  #>  9 2016 [sample from… 20160… GSS 2020 P… 1 [sel…      0.957         NA     1.09  #> 10 2016 [sample from… 20160… GSS 2020 P… 0 [not…      0.957         NA    NA     #> # ℹ 5,205 more rows #> # ℹ 4,289 more variables: wtssnr_1a <dbl>, wtssnr_1b <dbl>, wtssnr_2 <dbl>, #> #   vstrat_1a <dbl>, vstrat_1b <dbl>, vstrat_2 <dbl>, vpsu_1a <dbl>, #> #   vpsu_1b <dbl>, vpsu_2 <dbl>, year_1a <int>, year_1b <int>, year_2 <int>, #> #   id_1a <dbl>, id_1b <dbl>, id_2 <dbl>, mar1_1a <dbl+lbl>, mar2_1a <dbl+lbl>, #> #   mar3_1a <dbl+lbl>, mar4_1a <dbl+lbl>, mar5_1a <dbl+lbl>, mar6_1a <dbl+lbl>, #> #   mar7_1a <dbl+lbl>, mar8_1a <dbl+lbl>, mar9_1a <dbl+lbl>, …

title: Download GSS data file for a single year from NORC — gss_get_yr
code: gss_get_yr(   year = 2024,   url = "https://gss.norc.org/documents/stata/",   fname = "_stata",   ext = "zip",   dest = "data-raw/",   save_file = c("n", "y") )

title: Download GSS data file for a single year from NORC — gss_get_yr
text: year desired GSS survey year, number (.e., quotes). Defaults 2024. url Location file. Defaults current NORC URL Stata files. fname Non-year filename component. Defaults '_stata'. Usually changed. ext File name extension. Defaults 'zip'. Usually changed. dest save_file "y", directory put file . Defaults data-raw current directory. save_file Save data file well loading object. Defaults 'n'.

what: General Social Survey Survey 2020 Panel Data — gss_panel20
title: General Social Survey Survey 2020 Panel Data — gss_panel20
text: tibble containing General Social Survey 2020 Panel Data File, wide format.

title: General Social Survey Survey 2020 Panel Data — gss_panel20
code: data(gss_panel20)

title: General Social Survey Survey 2020 Panel Data — gss_panel20
text: tibble 5,215  rows 4,296 columns. Variables encoded labelled vectors. GSS Codebook authoritative source variables dataset. available http://gss.norc.org/Get-Documentation. Due COVID-19 pandemic, 2020 conducted GSS conducted two studies: (1) panel re-interview past respondents 2016 2018 cross sectional GSS studies (referred 2016-2020 GSS Panel), (2) independent fresh cross-sectional address-based sampling push web study (referred 2020 cross-sectional survey). data object first study; namely, study empaneling former 2016 2018 GSS respondents answer GSS questionnaire 2020 (.e., 2016-2020 GSS panel).
code: This data focuses on Wave 2 of the 2016-2020 GSS Panel – i.e. the panel reinterviews with 2018 GSS respondents and a randomly selected subset of 2016 GSS respondents. The GSS has used a panel format previously, as parts of the 2006-2014 GSS. In the 2016-2020 GSS Panel, variables only contain data from one of the three years. To differentiate between versions of each variable, they have been appended with suffixes. Variables from 2016 (Wave 1a) have _1a appended, variables from 2018 (Wave 1b) have _1b appended, and variables from 2020 (Wave 2) have _2 appended. Users can also track cases from 2016 and 2018, and reinterviews from 2020 with the variable `samptype`.  Because of its relatively complex nature, users are strongly encouraged to consult the official [GSS documentation for this dataset](https://gss.norc.org/Documents/codebook/2016-2020%20GSS%20Panel%20Codebook%20-%20R1a.pdf).

title: General Social Survey Survey 2020 Panel Data — gss_panel20
text: National Opinion Research Center, http://gss.norc.org.

title: gssr 0.8
text: Updated Release 2 1972-2024 cumulative data file. See official GSS page details. announcement: “Release 2 2024 GSS Cross-section data now available. updated data features questions related religious affiliation practice, industry occupation, household composition, new topical questions. encourage users review documentation consider potential impact experiments data collection approach survey estimates. Release 2 also reflects adjustments variables following disclosure review process implemented better protect GSS respondent privacy (details, see GSS 2024 Codebook).”

title: gssr 0.7
text: Updated newly released cumulative data file, covering 1972-2024. See official GSS announcement ’s new data file.

title: gssr 0.6
text: Fixed reshaping error 2006, 2008, 2010 panel datasets (gss_panel06_long, gss_panel08_long, gss_panel10_long) led values variables incorrectly attributed across waves. Thanks Pat Hastings identifying error. Updated 2006, 2008, 2010 panel datasets.

title: gssr 0.5
text: Split gssr two packages: gssr (data sets) {gssrdoc} (integrated documentation). Rationale: goal version package allow binary installs via R-Universe. binary package allows faster installation, matters gssr large package. Given current resource limits GitHub runners build packages, R-Universe can’t build gssr documentation. experimenting splitting two packages: gssr, contains data gss_get_yr() function, {gssrdoc}, integrates GSS codebook R’s help system. includes gss_dict object panel documentation object gss_panel_doc. recommend install packages.

title: gssr 0.4.5
text: Add get_which_ballots() function return tibble ballots question appeared . Add var_ballots list column gss_dict object, indicating distribution answers across ballots Q. gssr now passes R CMD check ERRORS WARNINGS Fix vars text like [NAME] [PROMPT] try autolink Rd build process.

title: gssr 0.4.4
text: Fix Rd files preventing PDF version docs building.

title: gssr 0.4.3
text: small fixes; bump min R version 4.0.0

title: gssr 0.4.2
text: Update gss_all Release 2a 1972-2022 Cumulative Data File (January 2024) Update documentation Release 2a also.

title: gssr 0.4.1
text: Fix 2022 2021 download years. working now.

title: gssr 0.4
text: Added latest cumulative file (1972-2022) latest panel data (2020, release 1a). Integrated help: every variable cumulative file R manual page (like function ). can browse pages help viewer query variables name console ?, documented object function. gss_get_yr() can now fetch 2022 cross-sectional file gss_get_yr() now correctly downloads 2021 crossectional file Removed gss_get_marginals() gss_get_props() largely superseded new built-variable documentation. gss_dict incorporates additional information.

title: gssr 0.3.5
text: Added gss_dict alternative way looking documentation.

title: gssr 0.3.5
text: gss_get_years() renamed gss_which_years() make less confusingly similar gss_get_yr() function. former looks see question asked. latter pulls given year’s dataset GSS website. Update base URL gss_get_yr(). Thanks (@lindsaypoirier.)

title: gssr 0.3.4
text: gss_all now includes 2021 data release imported GSS 1972-2021 Cross-Sectional Cumulative Data (Release 1, Nov. 1, 2021). documentation tibble yet include 2021 variables.

title: gssr 0.3.3
text: New gss_get_yr function fetch specific GSS survey year’s data.

title: gssr 0.3.2
text: gss_all retain STATA missing codes IAP, Can’t choose, DK. (Thanks @dustinstolz.)

title: gssr 0.3.1
text: panel documentation tibble, gss_panel_doc, updated wide format makes easier browse variables.

title: gssr 0.2.1
text: Moved Travis CI GitHub Actions build testing. Minor warnings resolved.

title: gssr 0.2.0
text: Created drat repository gssr http://kjhealy.github.io/drat. Added installation instructions covering drat documentation.

title: gssr 0.1.0
text: Prepped initial release

title: gssr 0.0.0.9000
text: Fixed errors panel tibbles; removed panelr depenedency; added three-wave panels Wrote short vignette giving overview package. Cumulative Data File Three Wave Panel Data added. Added NEWS.md file track changes package.
